item.title: Azure Functions Flex Consumption (Private Preview)
item.description: Flex Consumption is a new Azure Functions hosting option that builds on the consumption 'pay for what you use' serverless billing model and gives users more flexibility and customizability without compromising on available features. The service is currently in private preview, with public preview scheduled before the end of 2023 (tentative). Please use this form if you would like to be onboarded for the preview.This feature preview has no SLA provided during the preview. Please DO NOT use the preview features in any production or critical environments. Participation requires transferring your data to other countries in which Microsoft operates, including the United States.  By submitting this form, you agree to the transfer of your data outside your country. Microsoft Privacy Statement https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839. For questions and feedback, please reach out to us here flexconsumptionprev@microsoft.com

item.title: Text Truncation and Wrapping in .NET MAUI
item.description:
Imagine an app without text; it would be practically non-functional, wouldn't it? 🤷‍♀️ Text is an essential element in any application, and handling it appropriately according to different requirements is very important. In this article, we will focus on techniques for truncating and wrapping text using the LineBreakMode property to enhance the readability of our text. Let's get started! 🚀
Let’s start! What is the LineBreakMode? This property allows you to control the wrapping and truncation of the text. Accepts an enumeration as a value, which contains the following values: ➖ NoWrap Its responsibility is to display only the text that fits on the device’s first line. This means the amount of text visible on the first line may vary depending on the size device. – [It’s the default value].
➖ WordWrap These values automatically move text to the next line at the word boundary. This prevents words from being cut off at the end of a line, enhancing readability and allowing text to adapt to various screen sizes.
➖ CharacterWrap Unlike the WordWrap function, this setting automatically transfers text to the next line based on a character limit. This sometimes results in line breaks that do not align with entire words.
➖ HeadTruncation It omits the beginning of the text, presenting only the final part in a single line. It’s best used when the text’s conclusion is most relevant to the reader, ensuring focus on the most pertinent information.
➖ MiddleTruncation Unify the beginning and end of the text to fit within a single line, replacing the middle section with an ellipsis, which consists of three dots (...)
➖ TailTruncation
It omits the end of the text, presenting only the initial part on a single line.
And our article is completed!  . Thanks for ready! 👋 See you next time! 💚💕 Spanish post:
➖ https://es.askxammy.com/truncamiento-y-ajuste-de-texto-en-net-maui/ Reference: ➖ https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/maui/user-interface/controls/label?view=net-maui-8.0?WT.mc_id=DT-MVP-50033

item.title: Building a Text Editor: the Gap Buffer
item.description: Prologue: The Agon 8-bit computer In December of 2022 I came across a new 8-bit computer called Agon. It was built around the eZ80 CPU, a modern version of the venerable Z80 processor that was popular in many 1980s microcomputers, and an ESP32 microcontroller for video generation using FabGL (now vdp-gl, a fork of FabGL maintained by me). The original Z80 was an 8 bit CPU with a 16 bit address bus, allowing it to access up to 64KiB of memory at a time.

item.title: AI and Mass Spying - Schneier on Security
item.description: Spying and surveillance are different but related things. If I hired a private detective to spy on you, that detective could hide a bug in your home or car, tap your phone, and listen to what you said. At the end, I would get a report of all the conversations you had and the contents of those conversations. If I hired that same private detective to put you under surveillance, I would get a different report: where you went, whom you talked to, what you purchased, what you did.

item.title: q3k :blobcatcoffee: (@q3k@hackerspace.pl)
item.description:
Attached: 1 image
I can finally reveal some research I've been involved with over the past year or so.
We (@redford@infosec.exchange, @mrtick@infosec.exchange and I) have reverse engineered the PLC code of NEWAG Impuls EMUs. These trains were locking up for arbitrary reasons after being serviced at third-party workshops. The manufacturer argued that this was because of malpractice by these workshops, and that they should be serviced by them instead of third parties.
1/4

item.title: Inline Snapshot testing in .NET - Gérald Barré
item.description: In this post, I describe how to use Inline Snapshot testing in .NET. Inline Snapshot testing is a technique that allows you to write tests that assert the output of a method or function. The output is stored in a snapshot file. The next time the test is run, the output is compared to the snapshot file. If the output is different, the test fails. If the output is the same, the test passes."
item.author: (Gérald Barré)
